fields.summary: On-demand user cube

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
With the increasing demand for advanced personalization (60s segments, placeholders in cxense content, flexible userprofiles), it's no longer feasible to pre-generate all possible outputs which means caching can no longer be used.

We are able to fetch most user events and profiles within an acceptable time frame, which means we can construct a user specific cube which can be used to perform super fast aggregations and filtering based on the user. The output from such computations can then be used to perform simple top-list/collabusr aggregations in the general cube over all users.

fields.description:
This is a placeholder to ensure this dependency is tracked.

To enable content recommendations based on dmp events (CXANA-4834) it is a requirement that the events used can be filtered based on event type, category, etc. in real time. For this to be usable in Content we would need a latency of <200ms for 90% of requests.

Full traffic filters are not a requirement, so creating a limited type of allowable filters is a suitable solution. See CXANA-4834 for examples. Most of these examples are similar to the existing collab* modes with filters, and these are the ones that are relevant for this epic.

fields.description:
A new workspace widget that display a calculate rate in percent (like CTR) by dividing the count of one DMP event type with the count of another DMP event type.

The widget is configured by selecting two DMP event types (like "impression" and "click" for advertising or recommendations, or "streamStart" and "complete" for video). 

The widget should offer both displaying the rate as an individual number or as a time series chart (like the CTR widget and the Impressions/CTR chart in the Content Widget performance report - attached for reference).

fields.summary: Add segment type lookalike

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Add lookalike segments as a first-class citizen with its own type "lookalike".

It should be possible to create a new segment of type segment, where it should be possible to configure the segment to be used for the lookalike model, in addition to other tuning parameters. It should be possible to have multiple such segments with different lookalike configuration for the same target segment.

Segment events for these new segments should be fed to the cube, similar to the existing lookalike segment events, but probably we need to add a new type since the existing events represents the segment being used in the lookalike model.

The new solution should not involve the segmenttagger at all, and thus new members of the new segments will be instantly added as they come along, which is a big improvement over the existing scheme which requires the segmenttagger to regenerate the segments.

fields.summary: Workspaces 2.0

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Motivation:
Workspaces was in the beginning two completly static views and has since been patched and modified to add functionality. This is mainly been done by adding support for user flexibility using the same building blocks that were created in the beginning. This has for the most part been a success story but we are now seeing the "final" limitations of the code. We see this primarily in two places.

1. It is very difficult to create widgets that have non-trivial, multiple request (possibly with inter query dependencies). Evidence of this is the amount of time it took to create the Segment widget, Funnel Widget and Document widget. Creating more of these complex widgets won't take any less time if the building blocks aren't changed.
2. Complex widgets, large workspaces are slow. The root cause of this is that there is a lot of stuff happening in the background (like network request state change) that will result on a complete re-render of the widget/workspaces. This is an expensive operation with our current libraries.

A further (smaller) issue is that the API cache is tied to the workspace/view. This means that if you navigate from view A -> B -> A you will have to do the requests for A twice, even though the first requests are still valid. 

Sollution:
Do a complete rewrite of Workspaces using modern tools (the same tools used to create most of the DMP app).

fields.summary: Tracking of visible impressions from content widgets

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
In addition to tracking impressions and clicks from individual recommendations in a content widget, we also want to track visible impressions.

When the first pixel of a content widget comes into view in the browser, we send a DMP event with type "widgetvisible" and origin "recs". With the event, we send a customer parameter named "widget" with the widget identifier.

A widget usually displays multiple documents. When the first pixel of a document becomes into view in the browser, we send a DMP event with type "documentvisible" and origin "recs". With the event, we send a customer parameter named "widget" with the widget identifier, and a customer parameter "url" with the url of the displayed document.

fields.summary: Cross team development in cx repo

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
We need to make development in cx scalable to multiple teams working in different teams and geographical areas.

 * Introduce the owner concept in cx repo. This is both to document who owns what, but also to enforce who should be involved in a codereview.
 * Replace redo build system with bazel. We need a more standardized build system, and bazel is built to support large repository with owner structure.
 * Generate IDE configuration. The current scheme with hardcoded IDE configuration has some problems, especially when working with other projects with different global rules.
 * Properly integrate cxbuilder with gitlab again. It's currently broken and requires developer to join #cxbuild on slack, which is not scalable with many builds.

fields.summary: Customer isolation - streaming/feeding

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
This will make it possible to scale our streaming infrastructure further and enable customer cube clusters for performance and more fine grained routing to reduce cost.

Requirements:
 * Unlimited number of streams
 * Global distribution
 * Load balancing over multiple servers
 * Read scaling by adding proxies which is independent of write load

A requirement for running dedicated clusters for customers, or for doing efficient reprocessing of only subset of the event stream, we need better feeding infrastructure. Another weakness of today's eventstorer system is that we can't load balance per request over a set of eventstorers; switching requires refeeding.

fields.summary: Scalable segment serving

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Split out segment serving from apiserver, since it has started to create problems for other systems part of the same process. These problems will increase with larger segments (as will happen in CXANA-5504).

We want this new service to be built from the ground up using our new technology stack, which involves mesos, consul and gRPC.

First version of the service should pull out the segment snapshot specific parts from apiserver, and provide a grpc based API to lookup segments for a set of users using a segment snapshot. The service should be running in mesos in all DCs and be resolvable using consul for service discovery.

This epic is meant to be a minimal solution to get a real production service running. This will serve as a platform for more advanced segment lookup features in the future, and be an example for similar services we want to develop.

fields.summary: Replace cassandra with postgresql in analytics

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
We no longer want to use cassandra, and this epic deals with removing the analytics cassandra.

1. We need postgresql running with at least 3 postgresql replicas in each DC.A single postgresql master with manual failover is fine, but master downtime must not bring down any read-only replicas.
2. Set up analytics to write both to cassandra and postgresql.
3. Run with both cassandra and postgresql for a time, until we are sure postgresql has correct data.
4. Start reading from postgresql instead of cassandra. This must only be done once postgresql is setup for comparable or better availability than cassandra. See INFRA-444 for details.
5. Once all processes has been running stable long enough on top of postgresql, we can remove writes to cassandra.
6. Remove cassandra
7. Start taking advantage of SQL/postgresql

Until the last point, we should aim to have a simple postgresql schema, which can be used by CassandraKeyValueStore. Once we have removed cassandra, we can start to update or replace the code to get a more sane way of dealing with the database.

Please not that this epic will only require a minimal solution necessary to replace cassandra with postgresql. Cleaning up our database model with new tables and classes will be done in a later epic.

fields.summary: Ability to push DMP events through pixel tracker

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
In some cases, we want to track performance data from tags or sites that do not run our CX.js script. We want to be able to do a pixel request towards our servers with URL parameters that are forwarded as a DMP event. One example could be tracking an impression fro a landing page of an advertiser that is not our customer, or a pixel tracker from an email newsletter.

Completion criteria for this deliverable is to have an API endpoint that is functionally equivalent to [/dmp/push|https://wiki.cxense.com/x/LI3CAQ] but provided as a HTTP GET request in a similar fashion as the [traffic event HTTP API|https://wiki.cxense.com/x/84gfAQ].

This API will not require authentication of the client, but it will need to identify a persisted query.

fields.summary: Reassign ownership of segments (admin only)

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
We should implement functionality where an admin can reassign ownership of a segment of a workspace to another customer.

The scenario is that an onboarder creates segments and workspaces on behalf of the customer and we would like to be able to transfer the ownership to another user when that is done. One work around today could be that they create a service user for the customer and keep the login for that, but a more elegant way is to allow for API support of moving ownership of segments and workspaces. Of course the code must validate that the new user exist and that it has necessary privileges (just the configuration could be considered a information disclosure).

If we implement this, we should consider how the feature should be working as we reduce the number of people with admin access.

fields.summary: Basic segment overlap reporting table

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Customers would like to see how a segment overlaps with all of the other segments that they use. We will introduce a new segment details view tab that displays the selected segment's overlap with all other segments in that site group.

1. Introduce a new tab in the segment details view with the title "Overlap"

2. Show a table with 5 columns where each row represent a segment in the current site group, except the currently viewed segment:

Column 1: The ID of the segment
Column 2: The Title of the segment
Column 3: Overlap (%) (How many % of the user in the selected segment is also in this segment)
Column 4: Overlap (Users) (How many user in the selected segment is also in this segment) 
Column 5: Display overlap users as a blue bar (as in the segment overview widget)

3. Loading data

Column 1 & 2 should be displayed immediately. The remaining columns requires separate queries per row and should be displayed when ready.

4. Color coding

Show color coding for column 3 & 4 using the same approach as for the compare dimensions view. Color coding can only be shown after all data is loaded.You should be able to toggle color coding on or off with a button.

5. Sorting

You should be able to sort the table alphabetically based on the title.
You should be able to sort the table ascending or descending based on the overlap percentage.

Sorting can only be enabled after all data is loaded.

6. Download as Excel

fields.summary: Be able to explicitly push what gets created when crawling

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Today, when a document is crawled, this gets backed by a document in the search index having a number of named fields. These field names are used downstream by applications (in particular Cxense Content) that assume certain names for those fields.

The overall requirement is that the downstream applications (in particular Cxense Content) should not care about if the document was crawled or pushed via /document/update: So if I push a document, I should be able to controllably populate a field in the search index that would have been populated if the document was crawled.

Some comments on the phrase "controllably populate a field":

* When a document is crawled, the phantomjs-based crawling subsystem by default creates some image-data fields in the search index, e.g., \{"dominantimage", "thumbnail", "thumbnailfullheightdimension", ...\}. It should be possible to specify these also when pushing, but in that case it's the pusher's responsibility that the pushed values for image URLs/dimension are valid. (This means that it's OK to push in image URLs that reside on servers outside of Cxense's own infrastructure.)
* When a crawled document's text (and the document's URL) is processed, the content processing subsystem produces a number of "prefixless" fields in the content profile, e.g., \{"category", "taxonomy", "person", "concept", "company", "location", ...\}. (In the search index, some of these for historical reasons end up in the search index as \{"kw-person", "kw-concept", "kw-company", "kw-location", ...\}.) It should be possible to specify the values of these explicitly when pushing. E.g., if "person" is explicitly specified, this overrides whatever we'd infer from the title and body fields using the built-in entity extraction logic. Since we want to have control over the "prefixless" fields and the empty namespace, it's OK if this happens via a whitelist.
* When crawling an HTML document, the document can contain <meta> tags whose content end up in the search index. All of these, too, should be allowed to specify explicitly when pushing. In particular, the "og-" and "recs-" prefixes are in a sense special and reserved for this, and are not ordinary customer-prefixes and we make special exceptions for these. E.g., if I via crawling and <meta> fields can have a field created in the search index named "recs-boogaboo", then I should be able to do this via pushing, too. Note that "recs-" and "og-" stuff only end up in the search index and not in the content profiles.

fields.summary: Offline segment creation and import based on Cxense users

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Scenario that will be supported is:
1. Bulk page view data export for all users with a Cxense user ID, for a given Cxense DMP customer, that consists of:
       .serverTime (==> UNIX epoch)
       .ckp (==> Cxense ID)
       .ip (==> IP address)
       .location (==>  URL)
       .agent (==>  user agent)
Any other page view data parameters for user sessions that can be exported alongside the list above is considered a bonus, but not required for external segment modeling
2. Create segments offline in a 3rd party environment based on evaluating page view data (commonly referred to as 'click-stream') for the entire audience population with a Cxense ID marker
3. Bulk import of externally created segments with a set of Cxense user IDs

More details in the related stories.

The work will probably include
a) Extension of existing event export aPI with new User ID
b) implement concept of "external segment"
c) API to create, delete, and update external segments
d) UX updates to show and interact (= report and delete) external segments

Even more details:

We need a mechanism for bulk import of offline generated segments with Cxense user IDs.

You need to provide meta data about a segment when it is created through the API (siteGroupId, name, optionally description, annotations, and active status), so that the segment becomes visible in the DMP segment UI. Instead of the segment being defined as filters, the segment is defined by an explicit set of Cxense user ID sent in through the API. (You must be able to use the same Cxense user ID as the one exposed through traffic/data, as well as external IDs.)

The offline segments should be able to contain at least 10 M users. One should be able to use the segment for targeting purposes within 1h after upload.

The segment will always contain the initial set of users, until the list of users is updated through the API. That is, the segment is not relevant for periodic tagging. Notwithstanding the above, the segment will organically decay in size with time, unless updated, as some Cxense user ID markers are lost with time. In other words, the "external segment's" size is not static, although it should be treated as a static user parameter within Cxense (not subject for periodic tagging).

One implementation option is to add an optional list of Cxense user IDs to the /segment/create and /segment/update APIs. You should also be able to read the list of user IDs for the segment through /segment/read. You cannot edit/modify filters for these segments.

The segment should behave like other segments when it is used in other APIs, like a filter for traffic queries or getting the list of segments for a user through /profile/user/segment.

fields.summary: Content service monitoring

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
The Cxense Content service is for all practical purposes not monitored and we have no systematic way of detecting that the service is operating outside SLA.  

We should have monitoring of the following parameters, combined with suitable alerts and playbooks:
* % of requests with non-5xx response (already exists in graphite via haproxy, INFRA-318 should fix prometheus data)
* % of request with less items returned than requested
* % of requests with no backfill
* % of request with no failed branches/modes
* % of failures for each backend service
* % of failures for each matching mode
* % of requests with no results for each matching mode

In addition, a generic content dashboard and a playbook for manually reported issues with the widget server should be written. This should includes steps on how to figure out if and where there is an issue and throttle/disable traffic to that dc.

For internal monitoring we also want to replace the statistics currently logged to disk:
* Cache hit rate per matching mode
* Response time histograms per matching mode
* Matching mode specific statics like on demand vs cached user profile usage
* (Timing per widget?)

fields.summary: Automated service management

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Hardware fails, and with enough hardware something will always fail. We are now operating at a size where handling single machine failures has become a significant activity.

Handling failures must be a non-urgent daytime job. We need infrastructure to keep a service configuration always running even in the presence of hardware failures.  This requires a number of services to be in place:
* Service monitoring.
* Service discovery.
* Resource management and service allocation.

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.

fields.description:
We have a strong dependency on Cassandra in our production environment, but currently we have no Cassandra champion or sustainable maintenance strategy for our Cassandra instances.  This represent a very high operational risk.

We have two possible strategies to mitigate this risk:
* Reduce our dependency on Cassandra.
* Build Cassandra knowledge and maintenance strategy in-house or outsource this responsibility through a commercial support arrangement.

fields.summary: On-call offshoring

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Our current on-call arrangement is extremely expensive.
* Direct costs associated with on-call compensation.
* 3 days worth of paid leave every week to comply with rest regulations.
* Poor work-life balance for developers who run shifts every 2-3 weeks.
* Long response time, up to 30 minutes, to qualify as passive work.

On-call works better with a larger development staff, minimum 30 developers.  That will not be the case for a long time.  Hence, we suggest a new arrangement where on-call operations is offshored and only escalations are handled from the Oslo team.

The following improvements must be implemented for this to work:
* Monitoring, playbooks and general documentation must be suitable for use outside the core R&D team and must cover the majority of incidents.
* Increase monitoring coverage, especially for Cxense Content.
* New process for managing the on-call and escalation processes.
* Systematic work to reduce the number of escalations.

fields.summary: Capacity monitoring DMP userprofile

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
h3. Goals

 - Define SLOs for /profile/user
 - Monitor SLOs
 - Build capacity plan for /profile/user using SLO monitoring

h3. Background

We need to measure our system capacity and system load over time, and use this information to predict when load will exceed capacity in such a way that capacity planning can be part of our normal planning cycle.

h3. SLO

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_level_objective

Every SLO we choose for /profile/user should be something we can measure, and they need to be connected to the needs of the business - they should be tied to business revenue and SLA from customer contracts.

For /profile/user, we need the define and measure the following SLOs:

 - Success rate (how many requests did we manage to return HTTP 200 by the total number of requests)
 - Latency (for example at the 95% percentile)
 - Quality (the number of requests we were able to return something - this could be divided up into multiple sub-SLOs for each user profile component)

See document [Analytics Service Level Objectives|https://docs.google.com/a/cxense.com/document/d/1alf8trJ36URU3eGEN1V0DtLAFj1JNu7cqE59WI26LbA/edit?usp=sharing]

fields.summary: Fully redundant data centers

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
We are currently operating our services out of three data centers. We must ensure that we can operate without perceived degradation in service quality for at least 24 hours with one data center complete off line.  The requirements are:
* No real-time dependencies between data centers.
* All real-time services available in all data centers.
* Two data centers must be sufficient to handle normal peak traffic volume.
* Recovery of the offline data center must be quick.

Custom Search is explicitly not required to be redundant across data centers.

fields.summary: Associate DMP events with Documents

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
I have split the tasks driven from this ticket into CXANA-5129, CXANA-5130, CXANA-5131. These can be prioritized separately. Closing this ticket.

------------

Based on today's meeting, we have decided on the following:

1. We use the exisiting articleId field for document/update. Will need to extend the format to allow non-numeric characters. This will make it more prone to problems caused by accidental text processing. We should make sure that "car" and "cars" becomes two different IDs. 
2. Erik B mentioned that there is an existing meta tag we can used to represent articleId without referring to "recs" in the tag. "cxenseparse:articleid" needs to be documented, and we can probably remove the documentation for "cxenseparse:recs:articleid".
3. For DMP push, we use a convention where our customers can send in a customer parameter with the name articleId to target a document for the DMP event. We need to make sure that a customer parameter can hold at least 40 characters. If 40 characters already is supported, no change is needed.
4. Cx.js sendEvent already supports sending customer parameters. No change needed.


-------------------------

When a DMP event occurs on the same page as a document, the DMP event is automatically associated with the page view event. There are however many cases where a DMP event related to a document occurs on a different page than the document. 

For instance, an "AddToCart" event for a Camera product can occur on a Cameras category page (instead of the details page for the product). A "Buy" event for a product can occur on the shopping cart page. In these cases, you need to associate the DMP event with a document ID.

Customers would want to use their own ID for the document (such as a product SKU or a video asset ID). The URL of the document is often not available when sending the DMP event.

One way to associate a DMP event with Documents would be to introduce a new documentId field for both document/update and dmp/push. When a customer push documents, they add their own documentId for the document. (You must be able to add the same documentId as meta tags when the document is crawled). When the customer push DMP events related to a document, they add the documentId in the DMP event.

There are several customer scenarios depending on this feature (flexible document widget, recommendations based on performance events, video recommendations).

In summary, here are the tasks I think are needed to solve the requirement:

1. Agree on a field to use as an external document reference in document/update (could be articleId or a new field) The field is intended to support the customer id "as-is". Max field length can be set to 40 characters, and we need to avoid character restrictions that block common id formats.
2. Agree on the meta tag used for marking up this field when the document is crawled (could be existing articleId markup or new tag)
3. Add a corresponding field to dmp/push. Using customer parameters is not an option, since this document reference will be a central concept used in the UIs and across several APIs.
4. Modify cx.js sendEvent method to support the new field when doing dmp/push from the browser

fields.summary: Crawler performance improvements

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description: We are currently crawling documents at a rate of approximately 30 docs/seconds across a farm of 10 crawlers (content workers) and 2 traffic servers.  This rate is too low to always keep up with demand, resulting in growing crawler queues.  This epic describes a number of quick wins to increase the crawling throughput by an unspecified rate increase.

fields.summary: Support AMP for all Cxense products

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
[Creating a ticket out of this to persist the request, too many emails flying around. We might want to split this into multiple more fine-grained tickets.]

Google is trying to introduce their Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) proposal as a standard on the (mobile) web:

https://www.ampproject.org/

Basically, sites that follow the AMP standard will rank higher in Google searches. It's not obvious that publishers benefit from this as AMP severely constrains the type of scripts that can be run on a page, but the sentiment seems to be that one "must" be AMP-compliant going forwards. Hence, we need to ensure that Cxense can be deployed on a publisher's site in a fully AMP-compliant manner. Since the AMP standard constrains where and how JavaScript can be executed on a page, this has implications on us and the recommended/traditional approach with cx.js.

For getting basic event data into Cxense Insight, we have published a recipe:

https://wiki.cxense.com/display/cust/Accelerated+Mobile+Pages+%28AMP%29+integration

There are plenty of loose ends, though:

* Not all features we support with cx.js are available when following the AMP recipe, e.g., capturing active reading time and probably other things as well. This needs to be documented.
* With the amp-analytics approach, the crawler is currently not able to pick up the site identifier. This will cause site validation to fail, and necessitates a manual override.
* For the Cxense Insight AMP-compliance, we might want/need to provide a richer and better recipe. For example, instead of using the vanilla amp-analytics extension we might want/need to partner with Google to develop a specific amp-cxense extension, or specialized ways to use the amp-analytics extension. Examples of companies that do this are Parse.ly, Chartbeat, ComScore, Pinterest, etc: http://www.parsely.com/docs/integration/tracking/google-amp.html, https://github.com/ampproject/amphtml/blob/master/extensions/amp-analytics/amp-analytics.md, https://github.com/ampproject/amphtml/tree/master/extensions, etc.
* We need to provide AMP-compliant ways to use our other products, too, and not just Cxense Insight. In particular, Cxense Content and Cxense DMP.

fields.summary: Support lts/dmp cross site filter/aggregation per customer

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
For customer cube enabled customers, it's now technically possible to support cross site filter/aggregation.

For example, this removes most of today's limitations for traffic/dmp requests over long periods for multiple sites.

We need to enable this both in frontend and backend.

For a use case example [from advertising or any other marketing/promotional campaign execution]:

BACKGROUND:
Most targeted ad/promotional campaigns are run across sites — i.e., RON = Run of Network — to ensure sufficient audience reach and campaign delivery to target audience.
The way by which our DMP handles performance events — such as clicks — happens through DMP Performance Events (as in via 'sub-page view' events), and all customers are keen to get reporting on these ('data that cannot be seen is too abstract'). At present, i.e., prior to customer cubes, such DMP Performance Event reporting is only available on a Site level, not at SiteGroup level. RON however is by definition a SiteGroup.

ENABLED USE CASE:
The reporting of almost all audience targeted ad/marketing/etc. campaigns thus needs to be available on the SiteGroup level (cf. RON in advertising language), which this development enables.

fields.summary: Reduce failures from widget apis

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Customer: Winnipeg Free Press
[Support Ticket 9534 | https://emediate1.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/9534]
[Support Ticket 9608 | https://emediate1.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/9608]

The widget server has been overloaded and returned 503 errors on several occasions in the last few months. Many of these are due to badly implemented parts of the code, and can be handled by fixing the software. The remaining are usually caused by various backend services causing parts of the widget server to slow down and ultimately fail.

Adding more hardware might alleviate some of these symptoms, but most of the issues would still occur.

We need to measure the amount of failures (handled in CXANA-5049), and investigate and fix the issues that are causing these failures. Specifically incorrect handling of error situations must be fixed so the system either fails quickly so failover can occur or correctly handles known error situations. Stories will be added to this epic to fix individual issues as they are found.

The task is considered complete when the measured error rate for a longer period (1-2 weeks) under normal load is below 0.1%.

fields.summary: Scalable and Flexible External User Profiles

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Currently, the external user profile can only store 40 key-value pairs for a user. There are many scenarios where customer would like to store much more user data. One example is 3rd party audience data, which could be a source for hundreds of data points that could be used for creating segments for advertising. Another scenario is capturing data CRM or Commerce data from the customer’s own business systems, using for personalization or marketing purposes. A current limitation that we need to address, is that the external user profile only allows for storing string data. Several of the scenarios require the external user profile to handle numeric data and objects.

Link to OPS:

https://wiki.cxense.com/download/attachments/21168413/OPS%20Scalable%20and%20Flexible%20External%20User%20Profiles.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1455016689982&api=v2

fields.summary: Integrate Maxifier solution into CXense Platform

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
*Phase 1*: Initial integration / Rebranding

1. Setup DNS maxifier.cxense.com to IP address 192.235.75.29  - @Finn Arne. 

2.1 Provide Maxifier test environment available on maxifier.cxense.com   (@Maxim)
2.2 Provide new CXense environment with new tab "Maxifier" with link to https://maxifier.cxense.com/webcpo/  (@Christian) 
Does it sounds possible? Or probably can you provide us access to some kind of dev stand?  It is hard for me estimate timeline for this point - but I assume that it should be relative easy - isn't it?

3.1 Rebrand current Maxifier ADMAX version and logos (@Evgeny)   (should be agreed upfront with smb on CXense site ?)
3.2 Release new version of ADMAX which will be use CXense SSO (@Evgeny) and deploy it into maxifier.cxense.com 

4. Review result, discuss different Open questions (see below) and deploy into production (all)


Open question to discuss:
Do we need provide access to Maxifier's current customers to CXense products as well?
I think - we need.  But currently it is our of Phase 1.  So I assume that we will have only demo accounts here and common clients only. 
We have a vision that current CXense users who hasn't Maxifier account - should see Demo data. (instead of empty system)
  It is a bit different from current CXense strategy - but I think it can be helpfull for Demo's as well as for upsell 


 We would like to decrese initial workload on our hardware from your current users and protect system from some anonimous newly registred users.
So we need to limit this access somehow to Maxifier ( e.g. do it on permission basis - only for big CXense clients - this list we expect re setup manually)


Timeline: 
   My initial expectation that all this stuff can be easily done in 3-6 weeks (depends on priorities)


*Phase 2*. (There is also important points - but it can wait a bit)

- Full integration CXense SSO bar into current Maxifier ADMAX design (Maxifier)

- Provide Maxifier's client seamless access to CXense products (Maxifier)
Solve question with failover and scalability on authorization layer (Maxifier)

- Discuss Common Infrastructure (monitoring, deployment of new clients and etc) (all)

- Address Security Issues with current CXense SSO (@Rolf, @Christian)

- Migrate all Maxifier client into new environment  (there is some techical question how we can transite current setting and DBs into new environment without affect client) (@Maxim)

fields.summary: Redesign external identity handling to reduce risk of data corruption

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Currently, one customer can impact another customer's data by calling addExternalId in a bad way.

We try to link and merge users as early as possible in the identity handling procedure. After they have been linked and merged, they are one user and always counted as one.

The problem occurs once a customer does something like this:

{noformat}
addExternalId(type, "unknown")
{noformat}

linking more than one user to the same value, often a static string. Examples are that the identity has been set to "undefined" (the string), "null" (the string), 0 (the number) and the md5sum of 1. In all of these cases multiple users were linked to the same user, in effect making them into one big customer.

This then leads to wrong numbers in Analytics when it comes to unique users, and broken user profiles etc..

At the time of writing, it is difficult to undo this damage, and a full undo isn't possible since the data is in essence lost. After one wrong linking, all the other identifiers captured with this user is also corrupted and set to the same internal global value.

For ckp, gckp, lst and cst, this isn't a big problem, as those are not directly under user control. Even if someone tried to abuse those, it would be hard since they would have to guess the other values. Since they do not stand to gain much, this has been deemed an acceptable risk.

The main goal of this epic is to reduce this risk by:

1) Avoid trusting the results of addExternalId as much as we do today
2) Make the external id be resolved query time, and also allow it to be deleted after the fact for when the user does something wrong
3) Convert "UniqueUsers" back to being something like "Unique Devices", and stop 2) from changing the numbers. Even if the number is better (in some ways) than unique users only based on ckp/gckp/lst/cst, it makes it more difficult to compare it to Google Analytics etc.

fields.summary: Customer isolation (infrastructure)

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
h1. Goals

 - Reduce number of OOM crashes
 - Reduce chance of killer queries
 - Reduce cost of requests
 - Enable Customer cubes for NTM in production

h2. Collections, events and keyword documents

We focus on create customer collections in the history cube server first, which is meant to replace all lts/dmp cubes and data in the global history cubes for the customer.

The following collection schema is propsed: history.<customerid>.customer

The following event types must have a list of customers attached (the rest can be ignored for now):
 * RepoLogEvent (the pageview analytics event)
 * DmpEvent
 * SegmentEvent (lookalike events can be filtered on)

The following container types must be written with a customer collection if it belongs to the customer:
 * user-external
 * user-offline
 * user-identity
 * content

h2. Background

We want to isolate customers as much as possible from each other. For example:

- Reliability - Problems with one customers should not affects other customers
- Performance - Aggregation, operations and other requests only need to access data for one customer.
- Security - Reduce the risk for exposing data for a customer to another customer. It's easy to delete or change data for a single customer, according to need.
- Scalability - Easy to cluster similar customers together, or separate out customers witch special performance needs.

As a consequence, we need to be able to identify which customer a request belongs to, and make sure all event and keyword data is sent to the correct customer environment. For events, this means we need to map a siteId to a set of customers, and for API requests we need to map a user to a customer.

The technical solution for the cube is to introduce the concept of cube collections, which acts as independent environments which shares nothing with other cube collections except for the JVM process it's running on. All data for a siteId belonging to multiple customers must be duplicated in each customer's cube collection. Clients will not be available to execute requests spanning multiple cube collections.

fields.summary: Standard taxonomy as opt-in-switch in site group configuration

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
The Cxense standard taxonomy (https://wiki.cxense.com/display/cxinternal/Cxense+Standard+Taxonomy) is an in-house proprietary dictionary with mappings from keywords to taxonomy node related to the keywords. The dictionary has been created for English based on best practices, and has been translated to a number of languages. We deploy this taxonomy to site groups upon demand (from onboarding, or the customer themselves). However, we do not have any way of ensuring that updates to the master dictionaries will be re-deployed to site groups using the relevant dictionaries. The standard taxonomy is deployed in the _-categories_ namespace, and will be processed as long term user interests in the user profile. Confusion as to which dictionaries/taxonomies are active for a site group is reflected by a large number of support/onboarding issues.

In order to simplify and improve deployment/maintenance of the standard taxonomy, we suggest that the standard taxonomy is enabled through the sitegroup configuration. This configuration should be admin only. This is further describe here: https://wiki.cxense.com/display/devt/How+to+enable+processing+with+standard+taxonomy+for+a+site+group

fields.summary: Analytics capacity increase

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
We need to increase the cube capacity in the Ashburn and Hetzner data centers.

Current hardware setup:
| History cube              | 12  x 128GB |
| History feeder            | 3 x 128GB |
| Site cube and feeder | 4 x 128GB |

We need to double the amount of memory available to the different roles above. We can either increase memory to 256GB or add new machines with 128GB memory.  All machines for a single role must have the same hardware configuration.

What operational/capacity problems does this solve?
* We will have sufficient capacity for event feeding.
* We will have sufficient memory for cubes to avoid out of memory conditions.

A more detailed plan [here|https://docs.google.com/a/cxense.com/document/d/1fEledd0uWK2QBX18hFs5yQ5tzsJb11yUvM6433kUsYU/edit?usp=sharing]

fields.summary: Service for cookie synchronization with 3rd party systems

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
A key scenario for CxDMP is integration with 3rd party systems, especially for exchanging data on users. This requires CxDMP and the relevant 3rd party systems to share a common user identifier. This is commonly achieved through cookie synchronization.

We already have a prototype cookie synchronization service running to synchronize cookies with Exelate. This service will accept tracking pixel requests containing an Exelate user identifier and log these requests. There is currently no support for actually updating user profiles or extracting user data from Exelate.

The goal of this epic is:
# Implement a production-ready and supported version of the Exelate integration.
# Implement a more generic version of a cookie synchronization service that supports common cookie synchronization patterns.

fields.summary: Scalable and redundant search/content statistics

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
All statistics for search and content are currently being pushed to a search cluster running in ashburn (known as stats.cxsearch.cxense.com or cxenseinternal). This data will be unavailable if we lose the ashburn datacenter. This will affect UIs on content.cxense.com and the 'search' tab on insight.cxense.com. The APIs /reports/search, /reports/recommendation and /widget/report does also depend on this server.

We have a few options to consider:
- Live with current lack of redundancy. High availability for special statistics might be less critical than other services.
- Replicate stats cluster to all data center. Treat it like sitesearch, and possibly add a common feeding queue for it, like we are considering for site search.
- Migrate the data into cassandra or a database. This seems like a better fit for the data, but we would need to implement a service (or use cubes?) for querying it. (I consider this the most reasonable long term solution).

fields.summary: Improve test conditions for cubes running on production data with real actual traffic.

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
We currently do our testing of cube-releases the following way:
- Implement unittests and integration tests
- the code is deployed as part of the daily deploy
- at some time after this, the cubes are restarted and the code goes live

The testing is normally done so that only one cube is restarted, to see the new cube behavior with real production data and real traffic. As we all now, no test can fully cover all the fun corner-cases of real production traffic. It also means that we have no way of testing the code before it merges, or see the code lie bfore it is really hit by customers. Since rolling back a cube is something that can take a few hours (snapshot and refeed, or restart and longer period of snapshot), this can be annoying to do in a safe way to avoid issues for customers.

We currently have several challenges around this:
1) The restart happens infrequently, so possible "hidden bombs" can be deployed and run by accident due to a machine restart etc.
2) There is no way to debug problems or performance issues without fiddling directly with production nodes.

This epic tries to cover part of problem 1, the hidden bombs, but major focus in on problem 2.

The suggested solution is to:
(first 4 steps are just to set up something that is really a replica of a production cluster)
1) Setup a separate new cube-cluster with the same number of nodes and a feeder.  This could be AWS or hetzner, more on that in the sub-task.
2) Add a site-cube with local feeder, like in production
3) Add a APIServer instance that only uses this cluster
4) Add this node to the eventforwarders so that they get all event-traffic, as in production.

Then, the special things:
5) Add a customized snapshot-procedure that just does it as quickly as possible, and at a time of day where it is not useful for developers. 
6) Setup a job to mirror traffic to production to the test environment. 
7) (Optional) Consider canned data for replay
8) Write logic to do auto-deploy of cubes. This is almost supported already, as the cubes can restart if an /internal/kill is sent to them. They will automatically refeed, so the only remainder is to add logic to auto-enable the cubes again after refeed (something we, by accident, also need for production).

An example use case is this week's production issues with historyFields. We seem to have solved the problem now, but we do not fully grasp why it is failing like it does. Issuing the killer queries to production is no longer possible (and not wanted :-) ), so the useful would be to have a separate cluster to do this kind of exploration and fixing, send the killer queries to an instrumented version of the cube, with the same data and the same traffic as normal production.. -> measure and find the solution.

This is also great to actually ensure we fix the problem.

Since this is an investment in hardware and work hours, the backend developers should confirm that this is something they actually would benefit from.

The process of setting up the cluster should be done by someone else than Erik and Thorkild to spread knowledge about this to the rest of the team.

fields.summary: Template for Survey Data Capture

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Typically for Gender / Age.

As an alternative to:
 - Buying 3rd-party data from data provider
 - Running normal (heavier-weight) surveys on a small percentage of the users.

The light-weight capture is just a popup with a message like
 - "Help us improve the service by telling us who you are: Male  / Female"

Visually maybe like two big image buttons with images of a man and a woman.

The survey should be targeted to 100% of the users.

Other technical aspects:
 - The survey should not hit everyone at the same time, but maybe be configurable to a time interval (e.g. 2 weeks).
 - The survey must be robust, so that it doesn't ask the question every time the user enters the site (e.g. become robust by first setting a cookie and not doing anything, but on the next visit, verify that the test cookie could be set and was persisted, and then issue the question.
 - Be cross-site capable, and only ask the question once per use, and not once per site per user. This means that there needs to be a way to check if the user already have answered.

fields.summary: Probabilistic cross device matching

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Lack of probabilistic cross device mapping is an issue in several DMP sales efforts. We should evaluate whether we can implement a simple solution to cover basic scenarios.

Brain dump. Split into multiple tickets as appropriate.

Today we keep a gigantic mapping server-side that maps multiple user identifiers to a "global identifier". When combined with customer-supplied external identifiers (login handles or hashes thereof, typically) this mapping enables cross-device user identification.

Such a "deterministic" linking is typically the most reliable, but several of our competitors in the DMP space are boasting about also using various statistical algorithms for inferring that multiple devices are used by the same person. May or may not be marketing-speak, but we should also have some kind of story on this.

Although the approach might be frought with some practical problems (e.g., see below), this seems like a decent fit for a data mining job in our offline processing framework (or some similar setup.)

Here's a relevant article where Krux, a competitor of ours, discuss this approach:

http://www.adexchanger.com/data-exchanges/the-cross-device-question-krux/

{panel}
VAIDYA: To add to what Tom said, in terms of data signatures we track, we use the IP address, the user’s device signature, their browsing patterns, where they browsed from, all of these different elements go into the [statistical] model. The model ends up computing a score that looks through cookies and says the similarity score between these two cookies is X. If X is past a certain threshold, we determine that those two cookies represent the same user across multiple devices.
{panel}

fields.summary: Fix refeeding of data to datacube.

issuetype.description: A big user story that needs to be broken down.
issuetype.name: Epic

fields.description:
Refeeding more than 1 hour is currently broken due to the new complex log rotation scheme.

We should consider implementing something new, which preferably can be adopted into a scalable and fault-tolerant for receiving and persisting incoming events.

Currently, we have this setup:

haproxy -> apache -> tomcat/eventreceiver.

Apache is responsible for assigning a timestamp and logging to disk. We have a few minor problems with this, since timestamps are not sufficiently unique or sorted.

Ideally, we should create a correctly sorted 1 hour chunks of logs with unique timestamps. Most of our system no longer relay on the eventreceiver, but uses the apache log directly to feed subsystems. We could potentially replace the apache/tomcat combination with a smaller and simpler server which only is responsible for writing the log chunks to disk.

Until the eventreceiver has been completely retired, we could proxy all traffic through the log-server.
